In Würzburg he became a member of the Catholic fraternity KDStV Markomannia Würzburg in CV. Following his studies, Peter Legge prepared for the priesthood in Paderborn Collegium Leoninum. On March 22, 1907, he received in the cathedral of Paderborn by Bishop Wilhelm Schneider ordained priest. His first job was as a vicar in the Diaspora community Gerbstedt in Mansfelder country, which belonged to the parish Eisleben. In addition to pastoral care for the small number of local Catholics, he was responsible for the care of mainly Catholic migrant workers from Poland, who worked there during the harvest and usually had to live under unfavorable conditions. After four years in Gerbstedt Legge was appointed on April 18, 1911 chaplain to the Propsteigemeinde St. Francis and St. Elisabeth in Halle (Saale). Even in the big city of Halle, Catholics were only a minority and the community had only extremely limited economic and human resources. Here Kaplan devoted himself to the community pastoral care of the poor and again the care of the employed there Polish migrant workers. He also took care of those who were released from prison and was the contact person for the Catholic Girls' Welfare Association in Halle. In addition, he was involved in student pastoral care and also took care of the social care of Catholic students at the University of Halle. Since Petrus Legge was characterized by particular pastoral zeal, a prudent nature and great negotiation skills - even opposite government agencies - and respected both Catholics and non-Catholics as a conversation partner, appointed him Bishop Caspar Klein in 1924 to the provost of the St. Sebastian Church in Magdeburg and thus to the Episcopal Commissioner for the eastern part of the diocese of Paderborn; In addition, he was given the office of dean of the deanery Magdeburg. In his time in Magdeburg Petrus Legge fell due to the offices entrusted to him - in addition to pastoral care - especially administrative tasks. These included the establishment of a large number of charitable institutions and the responsible participation in various associations and committees. Supraregional importance had its activity as a local leader of the preparation and organization of the 67. German catholic day in Magdeburg with approximately 40,000 believers in September 1928, at which also as a representative of the Holy chair in Germany the apostolic nuncio Eugenio Pacelli, the later Pope Pius XII. participated. In June 1932, Provost Petrus Legge was appointed honorary lord in Paderborn. Pope Pius XI. appointed Peter Legge in September 1932 as Bishop of Meissen. The episcopal ordination took place on 28 October 1932 by the Paderborn Archbishop Caspar Klein in the St. Sebastian Church in Magdeburg. His motto was Contra spem in spem credere. On November 8, 1932, Peter Legge was solemnly introduced as the 44th Bishop of Meissen in the Cathedral of St. Peter at Bautzen - the bishop's seat at that time. He was responsible for the pastoral and administrative responsibility for one of the poorest German bishoprics, which at that time numbered about 200,000 Catholics - who mostly lived in the Diaspora - and which consisted of 90 parishes with 169 priests. Obviously for political reasons Bishop Legge was on the part of the Nazis the unauthorized transfer of a high Reichsmarks in the Netherlands, which was the repayment of one of his predecessors to finance important institutions of the diocese, such as the diocesan administration, the seminary and the pastors took loans borrowed, as a personal contribution accused of a prohibited "foreign currency transfer". He was arrested on 9 October 1935, was in custody for several weeks and was sentenced on 23 November 1935 by the criminal court at the Berlin district court for "negligent foreign exchange" to a fine of 100,000 Reichsmark. Because of this condemnation Bishop Legge was prevented in the period from December 1935 to March 1937 at the fulfillment of his duties as Bishop of Meissen and stayed in his hometown Brakel. On the part of the NSDAP in Saxony, he was defamed as a "people's pest" and tried to prevent his return as a bishop in his diocese. Even the then nuncio in Germany expressed concerns about Legge's return to the Diocese of Meissen. The Vatican appointed Heinrich Wienken, who was sympathetic to the Nazi regime, as co-adjutant with the right of succession as the representative of the absent diocesan bishop. After negotiations between the church and the Nazi government Bishop Legge was able to return to his diocese in late March 1937. He then appointed his representative Wienken General Vicar. After his return, Petrus Legge sought to avoid open disputes with the Nazi regime, but he came because of pastoral warnings in his Epistle to the pastoral communities Hirtenwort in a serious time of September 15, 1939, in which he is clear his rejection of the war was again criticized by the NSDAP as a "Volksveräter" and subjected to spying, interrogation and threats by the Gestapo. In the following years he tried with great personal commitment through pastoral words and religious teachings in the various parishes of his diocese with reference to the Bible, the contrast between the promised by Jesus Christ his disciples as the "Kingdom of God" and the "Kingdom of Satan" - Historically meant here was especially the Nazi "Third Reich" - to make the Catholics of his diocese obvious. Only after the liberation from the National Socialist rule did Bishop Legge u. a. in his pastoral letter of September 1, 1945 publicly and unencrypted his assessments of the war triggered by Hitler Germany and its consequences as well as the oppressive function of the Gestapo during the past years. On December 28, 1950 on the way back from the funeral of the Berlin Archbishop Konrad Cardinal Count von Preysing suffered Bishop Legge, his companion Domkapitular Hötzel and the driver of their car on a slippery road in Lübben in the Spreewald an accident in which the driver was killed immediately , At first Bishop Legge seemed to be only slightly injured. However, he suffered as a result of the accident in March 1951 two consecutive strokes, which he ultimately succumbed. Bishop Legge was buried with great interest in the Nikolaifriedhof in Bautzen. The Solemn Requiem was held by Paderborn Archbishop Lorenz Jaeger, who paid tribute to the deceased in his mourning address as a "great prayer and cross-bearer".

name: Heinrich Wienken
biography:
Heinrich Wienken (* 14. Februar 1883 in Stalförden bei Molbergen, Kreis Cloppenburg; † 21. Januar 1961 in Berlin) war von 1951 bis 1957 Bischof von Meißen.
Heinrich Wienken empfing am 6. Juni 1909 in Münster die Priesterweihe. Er war anschließend als Kaplan in Münster tätig. 1912 wechselte er nach Berlin und arbeitete bis 1916 als Kaplan und Jugendseelsorger der Parrei St. Sebastian im Wedding. Ab 1916 wirkte er zunächst als stellvertretender Leiter bei der Berliner Caritas und von 1922 bis 1946 als Direktor der Berliner Vertretung des Deutschen Caritasverbandes.
1930 wurde er zum Päpstlichen Geheimkämmerer und 1934 zum Hausprälaten Seiner Heiligkeit ernannt.
1937 wurde er aufgrund der vom NS-Regime erzwungenen Abwesenheit des Meißner Bischofs Petrus Legge zum Koadjutorbischof des Bistums Meißen und zum Titularbischof von Arethusa ernannt. Am 11. April 1937 empfing Wienken im Dom zu Münster vom späteren Kardinal Clemens August Graf von Galen die Bischofsweihe; Mitkonsekratoren waren Joseph Godehard Machens, der Bischof von Hildesheim, und Heinrich Roleff, Weihbischof in Münster. Sein Wahlspruch lautete Vitam impendere vero („Das Leben der Wahrheit weihen“). Er wirkte bis November 1937 in Bautzen.
Nach der Rückkehr des Meißner Bischofs aus der NS-Inhaftierung kehrte Wienken nach Berlin zurück und führte dort als Leiter des Bischöflichen Kommissariates der Fuldaer Bischofskonferenz die Verhandlungen zwischen der katholischen Kirche und der nationalsozialistischen Regierung.
Wienken erreichte durch seinen Einsatz eine Reihe Erleichterungen für die geistlichen Häftlinge im Pfarrerblock des Konzentrationslagers in Dachau
Darüber hinaus schützte er zahlreiche Verfolgte des NS-Regimes und trat in den Kriegsjahren für Notleidende und Inhaftierte ein. Dabei galt sein besonderes Augenmerk den wegen jüdischer Abstammung bedrohten Christen. Am 16. Oktober 1941 sprach Wienken zusammen mit dem Schöneberger Pfarrer Adolf Kurtz bei Adolf Eichmann vor; so konnte Kurtz die 1939 für die aus dem öffentlichen Schulwesen als „Juden“ vertriebenen christlichen Kinder jüdischer Herkunft eingerichtete „Familienschule Oranienburger Straße“ vorerst weiterführen, deren Schließung bereits angeordnet gewesen war.[1] Insbesondere kümmerte er sich hier um die Schule, schrieb Lehrbücher, betätigte sich aber auch theologisch.
Nach Ende des Zweiten Weltkrieges führte er die Verhandlungen zwischen katholischer Kirche und Sowjetischer Militäradministration und war Kontaktmann zum Alliierten Kontrollrat. Von 1949 bis 1951 war er Beauftragter der katholischen Kirche bei der DDR-Regierung.

1951 wurde er zum Bischof von Meißen berufen und kehrte nach seinem krankheitsbedingten Rücktritt am 19. August 1957 nach Berlin zurück. Er wurde am gleichen Tag zum Titularerzbischof von Mocissus ernannt.Wienken erreichte durch seinen Einsatz eine Reihe Erleichterungen für die geistlichen Häftlinge im Pfarrerblock des Konzentrationslagers in Dachau
Darüber hinaus schützte er zahlreiche Verfolgte des NS-Regimes und trat in den Kriegsjahren für Notleidende und Inhaftierte ein. Dabei galt sein besonderes Augenmerk den wegen jüdischer Abstammung bedrohten Christen. Am 16. Oktober 1941 sprach Wienken zusammen mit dem Schöneberger Pfarrer Adolf Kurtz bei Adolf Eichmann vor; so konnte Kurtz die 1939 für die aus dem öffentlichen Schulwesen als „Juden“ vertriebenen christlichen Kinder jüdischer Herkunft eingerichtete „Familienschule Oranienburger Straße“ vorerst weiterführen, deren Schließung bereits angeordnet gewesen war.[1] Insbesondere kümmerte er sich hier um die Schule, schrieb Lehrbücher, betätigte sich aber auch theologisch.
Nach Ende des Zweiten Weltkrieges führte er die Verhandlungen zwischen katholischer Kirche und Sowjetischer Militäradministration und war Kontaktmann zum Alliierten Kontrollrat. Von 1949 bis 1951 war er Beauftragter der katholischen Kirche bei der DDR-Regierung.

1951 wurde er zum Bischof von Meißen berufen und kehrte nach seinem krankheitsbedingten Rücktritt am 19. August 1957 nach Berlin zurück. Er wurde am gleichen Tag zum Titularerzbischof von Mocissus ernannt.
biography_eng: Heinrich Wienken (born February 14, 1883 in Stalförden near Molbergen, Cloppenburg, † January 21, 1961 in Berlin) was from 1951 to 1957 Bishop of Meissen. Heinrich Wienken was ordained a priest on June 6, 1909 in Münster. He then worked as a chaplain in Münster. In 1912 he moved to Berlin and worked until 1916 as a chaplain and youth chaplain of the parish of St. Sebastian in Wedding. From 1916 he worked first as a deputy head at the Berlin Caritas and from 1922 to 1946 as director of the Berlin representation of the German Caritas Association. In 1930 he was appointed Papal Privy Councilor and in 1934 the House prelate of His Holiness. In 1937 he was appointed Coadjutor Bishop of the Diocese of Meissen and Titular Bishop of Arethusa due to the forced by the Nazi regime absence of Meissen Bishop Petrus Legge. On April 11, 1937 Wienken received in the Cathedral of Münster by later Cardinal Clemens August Graf von Galen, the episcopal ordination; Co-consecrators were Joseph Godehard Machens, Bishop of Hildesheim, and Heinrich Roleff, Auxiliary Bishop in Münster. His motto was Vitam impendere vero ("To consecrate the life of truth"). He worked until November 1937 in Bautzen. After the return of the Bishop of Meissen from the Nazi imprisonment Wienken returned to Berlin, where he led the negotiations between the Catholic Church and the National Socialist government as the head of the Episcopal Commission of the Fulda Bishops' Conference. Wienken achieved through his use a number of facilities for the spiritual prisoners in the pastor block of the concentration camp in Dachau In addition, he protected many persecuted Nazi regime and entered in the war years for the needy and imprisoned. His special attention was given to Christians threatened because of Jewish descent. On October 16, 1941 Wienken spoke together with the Schoeneberg pastor Adolf Kurtz in front of Adolf Eichmann; so Kurtz was able to continue for 1939 for the out of the public school system as "Jews" expelled Christian children of Jewish descent established "Family School Oranienburger road", whose closure had already been ordered. In particular, he took care of the school here, wrote textbooks, but also worked theologically. After the end of the Second World War, he led the negotiations between the Catholic Church and the Soviet Military Administration and was a contact person to the Allied Control Council. From 1949 to 1951 he was commissioner of the Catholic Church in the GDR government. In 1951 he was appointed Bishop of Meissen and returned to Berlin after his illness-related resignation on 19 August 1957. He was appointed Titular Archbishop of Mocissus on the same day. Through his mission, Vienken achieved a number of facilities for the spiritual prisoners in the parish block of the Dachau concentration camp. In addition, he protected many victims of the Nazi regime and entered the war for the needy and imprisoned. His special attention was given to Christians threatened because of Jewish descent. On October 16, 1941 Wienken spoke together with the Schoeneberg pastor Adolf Kurtz in front of Adolf Eichmann; so Kurtz was able to continue for 1939 for the out of the public school system as "Jews" expelled Christian children of Jewish descent established "Family School Oranienburger road", whose closure had already been ordered. In particular, he took care of the school here, wrote textbooks, but also worked theologically. After the end of the Second World War, he led the negotiations between the Catholic Church and the Soviet Military Administration and was a contact person to the Allied Control Council. From 1949 to 1951 he was commissioner of the Catholic Church in the GDR government. In 1951 he was appointed Bishop of Meissen and returned to Berlin after his illness-related resignation on 19 August 1957. He was appointed Titular Archbishop of Mocissus the same day.

name: Otto Spülbeck
biography:
Otto Spülbeck CO (* 8. Januar 1904 in Aachen; † 21. Juni 1970 in Mittweida) war von 1958 bis zu seinem Tod Bischof des katholischen Bistums Meißen. Er nahm am Zweiten Vatikanischen Konzil teil und suchte dessen Beschlüsse mittels einer Diözesansynode im eigenen Bistum umzusetzen.
Otto Spülbeck wurde als Sohn einer Arztfamilie geboren. Nach der Schulzeit studierte er von 1923 bis 1924 zunächst Naturwissenschaften in Bonn, suchte aber dort bereits Kontakt zu Theologieprofessoren. Von 1924 bis 1927 studierte Spülbeck in Innsbruck Theologie und Philosophie. 1927 wurde er zum Dr. phil. promoviert. Er entschied sich, Seelsorger in der Diaspora zu werden und trat nach dem Abschluss des Theologiestudiums in Tübingen deshalb 1929 in das Priesterseminar des Bistums Meißen in Schmochtitz ein.
Nach seiner Priesterweihe am 5. April 1930 war Spülbeck bis 1937 Kaplan in Chemnitz und in Leipzig. Wegen des im Bistum Meißen herrschenden Priestermangels verweigerte ihm das Ordinariat in Bautzen den Eintritt in das Leipziger Oratorium. Gleichwohl orientierte sich Spülbeck bei seiner Arbeit an den Auffassungen der Oratorianer. So führte er, nachdem er 1937 zum Pfarrer der Pfarrei St. Laurentius in Leipzig-Reudnitz bestellt worden war, dort Jugendmessen ein, die er zum großen Teil in deutscher Sprache und „versus populum“ feierte, d. h. den Gläubigen zugewandt, an einem eigens aufgestellten freistehenden Altartisch. Damit war er an der Erprobung und Vorbereitung der liturgischen Reformen beteiligt, die später durch das Zweite Vatikanische Konzil für die ganze Kirche eingeleitet wurden.
In den letzten Tagen des Zweiten Weltkriegs wurde Spülbeck im April 1945 zum Propst von Leipzig ernannt. Seine schwierigste Aufgabe bestand darin, kirchliche Hilfe für die zahlreichen Flüchtlinge aus den ehemaligen deutschen Ostgebieten zu organisieren und die katholischen Schlesier, Ostpreußen (vor allem Ermländer), Donauschwaben usw. in die Pfarrgemeinden der sächsischen Großstadt zu integrieren. Mit den staatlichen Behörden verhandelte er erfolglos über den Wiederaufbau der zerbombten Propsteikirche.[1] Von 1951 bis 1955 war er gleichzeitig Geschäftsführer des St.-Benno-Verlages.

Auch als Priester interessierte sich Spülbeck weiter für naturwissenschaftliche Fragen und hielt zahlreiche Vorträge zu diesem Themenbereich. Sein Anliegen war es aufzuzeigen, dass die naturwissenschaftliche Erkenntnis und der christliche Glaube einander nicht widersprechen. Aus seinen Vorträgen entstand das Buch Der Christ und das Weltbild der modernen Naturwissenschaften, dessen erste Auflage 1948 erschien.Am 28. Juni 1955 ernannte ihn Papst Pius XII. auf Vorschlag des erkrankten Bischofs Heinrich Wienken zum Koadjutor und zum Titularbischof von Christopolis. Am 25. Juli 1955 spendete ihm der Bischof von Berlin, Wilhelm Weskamm, die Bischofsweihe. Mitkonsekratoren waren Weihbischof Joseph Freusberg aus Erfurt und Weihbischof Franz Hengsbach aus Paderborn.
Drei Jahre darauf wurde er zum residierenden Bischof von Meißen ernannt und am 24. Juli 1958 im Dom zu Bautzen inthronisiert. Sein Wahlspruch lautete: Unum in veritate et laetitia („Eins in der Wahrheit und in der Freude“).
Bischof Spülbeck machte durch offene Kritik am SED-Regime und als Fürsprecher eines wiedervereinigten Deutschlands auf sich aufmerksam. Während des Kölner Katholikentags 1956 hielt er eine Predigt, die in beiden Teilen Deutschlands erhebliches Aufsehen erregte.[1] Darin brachte er mit dem Bild vom „fremden Haus“ die grundsätzliche Verschiedenheit von Kirche und Staat in der DDR aufgrund weltanschaulicher Differenzen zum Ausdruck. Eine Zusammenarbeit von Kirche und Staat hielten Spülbeck und die übrigen ostdeutschen Bischöfe deshalb für ausgeschlossen.
„Wir leben in einem Haus, dessen Grundfesten wir nicht gebaut haben, dessen tragende Fundamente wir sogar für falsch halten. Dieses Haus bleibt uns ein fremdes Haus. Wir leben nicht nur kirchlich in der Diaspora, sondern auch staatlich.“

In einem Hirtenschreiben vom November 1956 kritisierte Spülbeck, wenn auch in vorsichtiger Form, die gewaltsame Niederschlagung des ungarischen Aufstands, die von der SED-Propaganda als Schlag gegen den „Horthy-Faschismus“ gefeiert worden war.[3]
biography_eng: Otto Spülbeck CO (born January 8, 1904 in Aachen, † June 21, 1970 in Mittweida) was from 1958 until his death, bishop of the Catholic diocese of Meissen. He participated in the Second Vatican Council and sought to implement its decisions through a diocesan synod in its own diocese. Otto Spülbeck was born the son of a doctor's family. After school, he studied from 1923 to 1924, first natural science in Bonn, but there already sought contact with theology professors. From 1924 to 1927 Spülbeck studied theology and philosophy in Innsbruck. In 1927 he was appointed Dr. Ing. phil. PhD. He decided to become a pastor in the diaspora and joined after completing the study of theology in Tübingen therefore 1929 in the seminary of the Diocese of Meissen in Schmochtitz. After his ordination on April 5, 1930 Spülbeck was until 1937 chaplain in Chemnitz and in Leipzig. Because of the lack of priests in the Diocese of Meissen, the Ordinariate in Bautzen refused to allow him to enter the Leipzig Oratory. Nevertheless, Spülbeck oriented his work on the views of Oratorians. Thus, after he had been appointed pastor of the parish of St. Lawrence in Leipzig-Reudnitz in 1937, he introduced there youth fairs, which he celebrated to a large extent in German and "versus populum", d. H. facing the faithful, at a specially erected altar table. He was involved in the testing and preparation of the liturgical reforms that were later initiated by the Second Vatican Council for the whole Church. In the last days of the Second World War Spülbeck was appointed in April 1945 to provost of Leipzig. His most difficult task was to organize church aid for the numerous refugees from the former German eastern territories and to integrate the Catholic Silesians, East Prussians (especially Ermländer), Danube Swabians, etc. in the parishes of the Saxon city. He negotiated unsuccessfully with the state authorities over the reconstruction of the bombed provost church. [1] From 1951 to 1955 he was also managing director of the St. Benno publishing house. Also as a priest Spülbeck continued to be interested in scientific questions and gave numerous lectures on this topic. His concern was to show that scientific knowledge and the Christian faith do not contradict each other. From his lectures, the book The Christian and the worldview of modern natural sciences, whose first edition appeared in 1948. On 28 June 1955 appointed him Pope Pius XII. At the suggestion of the sick Bishop Heinrich Wienken as Coadjutor and Titular Bishop of Christopolis. On July 25, 1955, the Bishop of Berlin, Wilhelm Weskamm, gave him episcopal ordination. Co-consecrators were Auxiliary Bishop Joseph Freusberg from Erfurt and Auxiliary Bishop Franz Hengsbach from Paderborn. Three years later he was appointed Resident Bishop of Meissen and enthroned on July 24, 1958 in the Cathedral of Bautzen. His motto was: Unum in veritate et laetitia ("One in truth and in joy"). Bishop Spülbeck attracted attention through open criticism of the SED regime and as advocate of a reunited Germany. During the Cologne Catholic Day in 1956, he delivered a sermon that aroused considerable interest in both parts of Germany. In it he expressed with the image of the "strange house" the fundamental difference of church and state in the GDR due to ideological differences. For this reason, Spülbeck and the other East German bishops considered cooperation between church and state to be excluded. "We live in a house whose foundations we have not built, whose supporting foundations we even consider wrong. This house remains a strange house to us. We live not only ecclesiastically in the Diaspora, but also state. "In a pastoral letter from November 1956 Spülbeck criticized, albeit in a cautious manner, the violent suppression of the Hungarian uprising, the SED propaganda as a blow against" Horthy fascism "Had been celebrated. [3]

name: Gerhard Schaffran
biography:
Gerhard Schaffran (* 4. Juli 1912 in Leschnitz, Oberschlesien; † 4. März 1996 in Dresden) war Konsistorialrat und Weihbischof in Görlitz, Kapitelsvikar des Erzbistums Breslau für das Erzbischöfliche Amt Görlitz in Görlitz und Bischof von Dresden-Meißen.
Schaffran wurde als Sohn eines Lehrers geboren. Dieser war zuvor von Breslau nach Leschnitz am Annaberg versetzt worden. Im Ersten Weltkrieg fiel er als Offizier und die Witwe zog mit Gerhard und dessen Geschwistern nach Görlitz. Gerhard Schaffran besuchte zunächst ein Gymnasium in Berlin, legte aber das Abitur in Görlitz ab und studierte in Breslau Theologie. Nach seiner Priesterweihe am 1. August 1937 durch Adolf Kardinal Bertram war Schaffran zuerst Kaplan in Breslau, durch den Krieg dann Militärpfarrer und anschließend als Gefangenenseelsorger freiwillig in sowjetischer Kriegsgefangenschaft in Aserbaidschan. Nach seiner Entlassung ging er bewusst in die DDR, wo er Rektor des Katechetenseminars in Görlitz war und ab 1959 als Dozent für Homiletik am Priesterseminar in Neuzelle und als Gefängnisseelsorger wirkte. Am 24. November 1962 wurde Schaffran zum Titularbischof von Semnea und Weihbischof im Erzbischöflichen Amt Görlitz ernannt. Die Bischofsweihe spendete ihm am 22. Januar 1963 der Berliner Bischof Alfred Bengsch; Mitkonsekratoren waren die Weihbischöfe Friedrich Maria Rintelen aus Magdeburg und Hugo Aufderbeck aus Erfurt. Schaffrans Wahlspruch lautete Soli Deo.
Im September 1970 wurde Gerhard Schaffran zum Bischof von Meißen gewählt. Bis 1987 leitete er das Bistum Meißen, dessen Name 1979 in Bistum Dresden-Meißen geändert und dessen Sitz 1980 von Bautzen nach Dresden verlegt wurde. Von 1980 bis 1982 saß er der Berliner Bischofskonferenz vor. Ein Höhepunkt in seinem Wirken war die Ausrichtung des einzigen Katholikentreffens in der DDR vom 10. bis 12. Juli 1987 in Dresden.
Am 1. August 1987 nahm Papst Johannes Paul II. sein aus Altersgründen vorgebrachtes Rücktrittsgesuch an. Schaffran starb 1996 in Dresden und wurde in der Bischofsgruft der Katholischen Hofkirche beigesetzt.

biography_eng: Gerhard Schaffran (born July 4, 1912 in Leschnitz, Upper Silesia, † March 4, 1996 in Dresden) was Consistory and Auxiliary Bishop in Görlitz, Chapter Vicar of the Archdiocese of Breslau for the Archbishop's Office Görlitz in Görlitz and Bishop of Dresden-Meissen. Schaffran was born the son of a teacher. This had previously been transferred from Breslau to Leschnitz am Annaberg. In the First World War he fell as an officer and the widow moved with Gerhard and his siblings to Görlitz. Gerhard Schaffran first attended a high school in Berlin, but left the Abitur in Görlitz and studied in Breslau theology. After his ordination to the priesthood on 1 August 1937 by Adolf Cardinal Bertram Schaffran was first chaplain in Wroclaw, by the war then military pastor and then as prisoner of conscience voluntarily in Soviet captivity in Azerbaijan. After his release, he deliberately went to the GDR, where he was rector of the catechetical seminar in Görlitz and from 1959 worked as a lecturer in homiletics at the seminary in Neuzelle and as a prison chaplain. On 24 November 1962 Schaffran was appointed Titular Bishop of Semnea and Auxiliary Bishop in the Archbishop's Office Görlitz. On 22 January 1963, the episcopal consecrated him to the Berlin Bishop Alfred Bengsch; Co-consecrators were the auxiliary bishops Friedrich Maria Rintelen from Magdeburg and Hugo Aufderbeck from Erfurt. Schaffrans motto was Soli Deo. In September 1970 Gerhard Schaffran was elected Bishop of Meissen. Until 1987 he headed the diocese of Meissen, whose name was changed in 1979 in the diocese of Dresden-Meissen and whose seat was moved in 1980 from Bautzen to Dresden. From 1980 to 1982 he sat before the Berlin Bishops' Conference. A highlight in his work was the orientation of the only meeting of Catholics in the GDR from 10 to 12 July 1987 in Dresden. On August 1, 1987, Pope John Paul II accepted his resignation request for reasons of age. Schaffran died in Dresden in 1996 and was buried in the episcopal tomb of the Catholic Court Church.
